reviewText:
Early Access Review

========================================

Vince Rowe ReviewsSaving the Industry one Game at a Time!

[YouTube Link]   [Curation Link]

========================================


THIS REVIEW WILL BE UPDATED DURING THE GAME'S DEVELOPMENT

Grimoire: Manastorm is a fast paced Twitch FPS arena deathmatch primarily built for PvP, it has the potential to become highly competitive due to it's extremely high skill cap, combos and variety.


Pros:
+ Fast paced action FPS
+ Large variety in spells and classes
+ Dynamic spell-casting with an exceptionally high amount of combos
+ Huge skill cap
+ Easy to learn but hard to master
+ Huge re-playability
+ Relatively balanced for an early access game
+ Reasonable pricing
+ Consistent updates
+ Informative, Reliable and, Promising Developers
+ A lot of potential
+ Great with friends
+ Bots to fill in for lack of players


Cons:
- Extremely low amount of players
- Large amount of bugs (Early access)
- Graphics are bad
- Everything is typically too dark
- Multi-player only (other than Bots)
- Networking issues
- Limited animations


Overall this game is pretty fun, I'll be keeping tabs on this game and on the upcoming updates.



My Personal Experience:
I really enjoy this game. At this moment in time there's an enormous amount of content in the game - to the point where I'm still learning tactics, combos and overall simply how to be better at the game. For an early access game this is actually pretty impressive.

The combat in this game is really satisfying, getting kills is pretty damn fun! The only real gripe I have is that there's only one death animation where they just fall onto their knees and die... This is kind of boring to be honest but it is in alpha so I'll say this as constructive criticism - add in instagibs for overkills and various different death animations based on which class you use and that'll make the game much more responsive and make each class more unique.

On the topic of classes; they're all kind of similar to be honest, the Fire, Lightning and Frost all have the same first ability which is basically a close range, consistent attack which is kind of the same really but I expect that will change as the game is developed on more. The Arcane, Nature and Earth are more unique but overall they all share very similar traits which is kind of a shame really. I would like to see more status effects because at the moment there's pretty much only the slowing effect from frost.

This game has a lot of potential though, just by making the classes more unique and different adding in more play-styles it can really turn this game into something great. Then just by copying the structure of a lot of competitive games we have now such as Counter-Strike: Global Offensive with a functioning matchmaking system, leader-boards and ranks and there you have it! A fully functional competitive game.

The graphics are not great though, and by not great I mean 2004 Unreal Tournament Mod. They're bad and way too dark. It is alpha at the moment so I'll give it the benefit of the doubt and in defence for the developers the most recent update did make a lot of the spells look better.

Speaking of developers, these guys are great, every weekend they schedule play-tests - and in fact I played with them the other day (Saturday). They read the forums and respond to everything. They're pretty good guys and equally they're pretty damn good at the game too...

Overall this game is pretty fun, I'll be keeping tabs on this game and on the upcoming updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Grimoire: Manastorm is a very interesting and fresh take on the tried-and-true FPS gameplay. The style is reminiscent of the old school arena action of yore. The days of Quake and Doom echo through the very core of Grimoire: Manastorm, while modern MOBA-styled elements breath new life into it and entangle with Elder Scrolls-esque lore and powerful firey doom.

The central gameplay is entertaining and intense; overpowered wizards struggle in the streets of dingy cities and classic fantasy locales. Unlike the usual first person shooter, you trade in your pistols, shotguns, and rifles for Lightning, Netherworld Magic, and Flames.

Your characters burn, squash, and electrocute eachother to take glowing control points throughout the maps during Conquest, a tense and action-packed team play mode. The team-based combat already feels tight, and the use of tactics can turn the tide of the battle. A single fire wizard moving around the side and flanking the unsuspecting defenders with the use of their Ultimate ability followed by a flurry of fireballs can entirely change the flow of combat.

On the other side of the coin you might find Free-For-All a frustrating mess, or a great source of fun. FFA is chaotic, even by the standards of the Conquest mode. During an FFA match you will often find yourself wandering for a moment before becoming embroiled in the magical hell-storm unfolding in the center of the map. There's little breathing room and most of the time you'll find yourself flailing helplessly in the fray before being cut down by a lucky shot from someone hopping into the fight with full health just after respawning. Speaking of respawning... The spawnpoint system that is implemented in FFA leaves much to be desired. There have been numerous occasions where I literally spawn inside of another player, or someone spawns directly behind me.

Grimoire's initial offering might turn some away. The first match is so absolutely confusing that it feels like you've just been dropped face-first into a malfunctioning nuclear reactor and told to stop it from meltingdown. Okay, that might have been a bit of an exaggeration, but my point still stands that the first match or two might be so off-putting that you'll turn your nose up at it. The controls are a little hard to get used to, but my main suggestion would be to change the controls to FPS in the options menu. This style, I feel, should be the default as it is much easier to use and much more intuitive. Give it a few matches and tool with keybindings before giving up if you find your first match a bit too insane.

The game's graphics also leave something to be desired. The assets used for effects and the magical graphics are certainly fun to watch, featuring a uniquely stylized and fun look, but character models are rather flat. Textures tend to be muddy, and the ground in some areas looks like it was pulled straight from the Playstation 2. However, this is certainly excusable at the moment because you can already see what the developers are going for, and what they hope to one day achieve. However, the graphics aren't so bad that it makes it hard to play, and the gameplay is fun enough to make the visuals often fade into the background.

As it stands, the game is a highly playable and fun romp through chaotic medieval landscapes. While the graphics leave much to be desired, and more gamemodes would be appreciated, the current offerings are enough to provide a good deal of entertainment for the tidy little price of 10 USD (or for free if you got your key from PC Gamer's giveaway). I have only high expectations for the future of this game, and look forward to seeing it improve and to take part in it. For now, I've spent enough time writing out this review, I think it's high time that I put my pointy hat back on and start slinging spells in the courtyard. I hope to see you folks on the field. For House Validus!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions upon getting into a match wasn't great to be honest, the presentation, lack of any tutorial and basically the whole pre alpha-ness of the game made me groan at what i thought was just another shoddy early access game.
Now after a couple of matches i'm ashamed to have doubted this delightful and refreshingly frantic FPS. Having full team mage battles is incredible as there are no mana costs on spells so ice winds and fire storms are just flying everywhere while you dodge and weave around the back and steal the control points.

Yeah the look of the game currently isn't anything to bust a nut over yet, but i've honestly not had this much fun in an online FPS in ages. Looking very much forward to what the game will look like out of early access, so i'ma buy this tasty gem and hope others do too as i want more massive mage throwdowns.

Just please change the hands in first person, they are flopping all over the place, and also add different spell effects that appear in the right hand as i need that visual feedback to know what spell i've got selected. I’ve got partial poo brain.

If you ever thought about Magica Wizard Wars converted to 3D ( with MOBA like spell powers) your wishes have come true. However this is still alpha so this game has poor graphics, its unblanced (fire mage pls) when it comes to all 5 types of mages, every map resembles previous one, in adittion minimap wants you to belive that this locations are big, but it takes up to 10 seconds to get from point to point (on some maps). Nevertheless, if you find full server this game provides decent amount of pure enjoyment coming from mage FPS/MOBA doom party, I did not expirience lag issue BIG PLUS (its still aplha 0.6 build so I expected a lot of laggy spells..glad that I was wrong). All in all, its definetly worth playing, but before they don't introduce more maps/game modes it is not worth buying yet. But if every thing goes according to devs ideas steam useres will soon (hopefully) play very unique and fun game called Grimoire: Manastorm.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keeping in mind this is an Early Access game, here is my $0.02.

I love this game. I love the concept, the execution, and the potential. It's fun, fast, and with proper support from the developers and community, will be an excellent game.

The graphics are not top notch by any means, and the UI's need a complete overhaul. The skills need tweaking and rebalancing. More animations and visual effects need to be added. These are all things that I, for once, have faith the developers will attempt to solve.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Grimoire: Manastorm is an amazing fast paced Magic based FPS, whether your in a tense 1v1 situation or a chaotic 4v4 with spells flying all over the place, this game is a tonne of fun. Utility spells allow you to alternate the play style of the class you pick, giving the game an 'Easy to pick up, Hard to master' vibe to it. Meaning that skill has a big part to play, 'Mind games' and strategy with teleport and mana dashing, even a well timed Stoneskin during your opponents ultimate or other large cooldowns can win you a fight with ease.

I'd give it an 8/10 (bear in mind this review is while it's still in Alpha testing)
I'd only give it an 8/10 due to the few bugs which are to be expected, but also to the seeming lack of community which I'm sure can only grow with time. This game is run by a small group of indie devs 5 or 6 in total I believe, not to mention the fact they have just lost their lead programmer a few weeks ago. Although he wasn't their only programmer it will obviously damage the development of the game drastically, in addition losing a member in such a small group of devs also makes a huge difference to progress.

This game has so much potential, it will take time to get there but when it does I'm certain this will be a masterpice to behold.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wizards aren’t very agile creatures, so making them the main characters in an FPS might seems like a strange choice. You won’t be sprinting across the battlefield, you can’t even crouch due to your elderly wizard knees. Your only weapon will be your bare hands and the element of your choice. Destroy your foes with fire, lightning, or even the power of the nether. Currently there are 6 classes, each offering their own unique playstyle. While some class roles are fairly obvious, like nature wizards having the ability to heal, the actual execution is entirely up to you. Tweaking your playstyle is made even easier by allowing you to pick your own “utility” and “mobility” spells. Feel like blasting your enemies from a rooftop? Use a mobility teleport to get on the roof and rain destruction down. Playing a long-range class, but not great at aiming? Use a utility binding spell to keep your enemies still for a second. The action is fast-paced and based on completely on skill. It’s early access, but the potential is there. Here it comes, Grimoire- Manastorm!

The spell effects are pretty great, especially viewed from third-person. In first person some of them are a bit lackluster, but that is to be expected during early access. The character models look nice, as do the levels. There are control point and team deathmatch game modes available. It’s a pretty awesome feeling, watching two teams of wizards slinging spells at each other. Spells move at different speeds, but most are able to be dodged with some quick reflexes. You are able to use a blink called “mana-step” to traverse ground quickly. Mana-step is the only skill that seems to use mana, which means you can sling all the spells you please. Not worrying about mana makes the combat much more frantic, as neither wizard will generally ever stop casting during combat. Blinking behind a cart to dodge an icebolt and returning fire with your own spell school is intense, and with a full server the action is constant.

There doesn’t seem to be any damage multipliers based on elemental strengths and weaknesses, a la Pokemon, but I think it would be a nice addition to strengthen the class-based gameplay. The classes seem to still require some tweaking and balancing. My roommate and I both found ice to be extremely overpowering to almost any other class. Ice is a relatively close-range class, so picking lightning and striking from afar seems to castrate your opponent relatively well. Aiming better than your opponent is really less than half of the battle. Knowing which spells your opponents are likely to use, and how to counter them is what will end up winning wars. Thinking on your feet, and using wits along with clever use of spells is exactly what being a mage is all about, and to see it come to life in such a fantastic way is something to behold. However, it is still early access, so there are a couple of blemishes.

The biggest obstacle the game will need to overcome is a loyal player-base. There are dev playtests 3 times weekly, which makes it relatively easy to get the full experience but in off-hours most matches you find will be 1v1. I would like to see a free-for-all deathmatch mode, since the occasional 2v1 isn’t really a fun experience. There is also currently no music aside from the main menu, though that music is quite epic and mythical. I would also like to see a bit more variety in the levels, and to have the first-person spell effects be kicked up a notch. There is time for all of the above to be fully fleshed out, and if you can find a decent match, what is offered is amazingly fun. I suggest it to anyone who enjoys a real time battle of wits and reflexes whilst slinging a bevy of spells at your opponent. Thanks to Omniconnection for the review copy. Here’s to hoping Grimoire- Manastorm will blossom into what it deserves to be.

Summary: Amazing magic-based FPS with 6 classes and endless playstyles.
Final Score: 6/10 for gameplay, models, and spell effects.

This is an Early Access review to be updated on full release.
Full text/photo Early Access review: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-grimoire-manastorm-early-access/
Video Early Access review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4EzT3eT2LB8

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGrimoire: Manastorm so far is a great game that feels like playing RPG and FPS at the same time. It is thrilling to battle others using different styles depending on what class you are playing. There are 6 classes so far (Earth, Ice, Fire, Nature, Nether, and Lightning), each with their 4 unique spells. Even though learning the controls were hard for me when I started playing the game, but after two or three matches, I got a grasp of the game and started murdering my enemies. Grimoire is defnitely a game for anyone that loves multiplayer FPS games or even just a someone who likes playing fantasy RPG game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's an early access alpha right now. If you're unfamilliar with what that means, that means that it's not feature complete and a little rough around the edges. However, the structure is solid and the class structure is fantastic. The mage classes are all themed well and a blast to play--the interactions and gameplay between all their skills has quite a bit of depth, if you take the time to learn how they work properly. Each duel between rival mages feels different, and losing isn't frustrating because you can always think of something you could have done better.

As an added bonus, a group of friends and I were playing and ended up playing with the level designer and talking with him on voicechat while we murdered each other with fireballs. He was super cool and down-to earth. He took our feedback, and talked to us about the future direction for the game, which sounded awesome.

I don't normally do Early Access anymore, but this is one to make an exception for. If you don't feel like buying it, at least keep it on your list of games to check out again when it's closer to done--there's a lot to be excited for in this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First Impression
I logged onto the game and dominated with the fire class, while i feel like the class balance could use some work i still see potential in the game.

The game feels like a mix of Unrealtournament and Magica, fast pace and extremly fun once you get the hang of how the spells works. I had some issues joining servers in the beginning but simply rejoining 1-2 times solved the issue and i have not crashed since.

I have have spoken to one of the developers, and i get the impression that they really care about the game which can't be said about many game developers out there.

Verdict
If i where to give this game rating i would give it 6/10, they have some work infront of them but i am sure with time that 6/10 would be a soild 10.
Is it worth €12.99? Well that is entierly up to you, i bought mine on the 50% sale and i would still have bought it for 12.99 after trying the free weekend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just some early thoughts on the game!!

http://gamerssanctum.net/?p=1398

With the huge amount of games available to us through Steam it is very easy to overlook all the smaller games in development. Let's face it, the only reason you know about a lot of the game you are playing right now is because people like us play them and tell you whether they are good or not. The huge flood of Early Access games to hit Steam, and some of the developers bailing on their projects don't help matters at all.

So I guess the question to ask is whether Grimoire: Manastorm is a good game, or do we watch it crash and burn? In its current state I would say that it definitely has potential to be a great multiplayer game. Although the game does barrow from the competitive multiplayer games that came before it, I feel it does a great job of setting itself apart through the combat system. It does follow the standard first person view and arena style map, but it relies on spells instead of guns. This is actually one of the games features that gives it some originality, and makes it a lot of fun. During the course of a match you are attempting to out score the other team via capture points on the map. The guys developing the game didn't invent this style of play but they adapted it to fit their game pretty well.

When it comes to killing the opposing team you definitely have choices. When you start up a match you can choose between Earth, Lightning, Ice, Fire, Nature and Nether for your class. You also have some options for utility and travel spells which help augment our play style. These include spells like Teleport, Repel, Stoneskin, Arcane Barrier, etc. Although each class has the same basic attacks to deal damage they feel very different when you start unleashing the more powerful spells. You can tell when playing each class that later on each one will have a role in a team composition. Since each class has a different set of powerful abilities team composition will become important when playing, like in every other multiplier game.

So is the game worth it? For the huge sum of $13.00, yes, it is worth it. I have spent $50.00 on a game and completely regretted ever loading it up. In the case of Grimoire, it only lacks people to play with. Like every other multiplayer game it requires people to play against each other to be fun. Given some time to polish and balance the game, we could easily see this being a great game that many people will be playing in the future.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI waited for this download for well over 4 hours, starting sometime in the early hours of the morning and only getting to play it well past lunch, my internets been really crap as of late, not the point. THE POINT IS! and this is simple, this game was completely worth the wait, I mean, the lack of tutorial, the shoddy old school graphics, and the lagginess that comes from playing on a server no where near australia, reminded me of my old gaming days when I was younger, it's not hard to jump in, check out the controls, they are really simple, and you can choose between two setups, an FPS - choose your weapon/spell style of setup where you have each spell to flick through from numbers 1 to 4 or you can have the quick shot setup which puts each of the 4 spells in a conveniant place near your fingers, you won't find yourself reaching out of the way to hit a spell button from across the keyboard, even the dash or manawalk" or whatever its been called

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first access title, and the experience was... Awesome! Even though I'm not a fan of this genre, I still managed to enjoy this game on a major level! This game proves that not all developers are greedy-♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that need some quick cash.
Already from the start you get about 6-8 classes (don't judge me, I didn't focus on counting lel), and a ♥♥♥♥ ton of unique powers for each and every one of them. All of the classes have common powers like teleportation.
Using the shift button is a must at most dangerous situations.
The graphics could be better, but since the gameplay is awesome, you shouldn't really mind it...
The only flaw that I find pretty much attention-taking is the overpoweredness (if I could say that) of the fire class.
Overall, an awesome game! I really hope that the developer, who we played with a few nights ago, will do a great job on making this game even better :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an EA Alpha game running this smooth for me: 9/10

Wizard fpc {First person caster ;) ) you have the choice between 6 unique classes. Each utilizes it's own style with 4 personal attack and a passive. You then have a choice between 2 utility perks that all share and complete the skillset. Using that, your team of 5  will attempt to take over the most control points while gaining them for kils as well

To my feelings after I played them, this is how each felt to me, of course basing it off how much the damage output and range was:

Fire: Feels like your all aout assault class
Ice: Gives you more crowd control
Lightning: Feels more like your long range damage
Earth: Defensive
Nether:  AoE based, good for controlling ground
Nature: Healer with AoE style

Pros:
Runs great for a 2 month old Alpha
Classes diverse enough
Multipul maps
Not alot of downtime
No class levels
Streamlined setup selection

Areas to Improve:
(Can't be called cons, this is a 2 month old EA Alpha)
The game is relatively new, Server list will most likely pick up as player base does. My only concern was no tutorial or documentation which can give you a fuzzy first 5 minutes, but this is something they can easily code in later. There is a Player Level that doesn't seem to be implimented in yet, but tracks basic skills. I can see where this could evolve into a perk, rune, or some otherwise named account wide personalized playstyle system.

The free play endded a bit ago, and it's on sale 50% off, under $8 at the moment, so definently picking this up to see where they bring this game too

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Grimoire Manastorm...
[First we must start by knowing that I am a *little* biased torwards magic games]

This is, first of all, an amazing game. I had always been kind of passively searching for a good mage game where you could hopefully do some pvp or at least duel other players. I first saw Grimoire back when the free weekend happened. I was apprehensive about it at first because I didnt want to come across another gimpy-mages-doing-lame-tricks game, that would have discouraged me from mage games for a while. So I tried it and to my surprise it surpassed my expectations. It had 2 modes, FFA and Team Capture The Points. There was 6 highly diverse classes and selectable Bonus Spells" Grimoire is a fast paced high intensity wizard game. My only complaint would be that player count day to day is not all there but that will be fixed soon and I would like class progression which is going to be added in coming updates.
Another plus is that the dev play tests actually help and they are really connected with the players."

Sad.. already I have came across players using hax. All abilities have cooldowns but these guys were casting same ability.. number 4.. constantly.. no cooldown. No I am not QQ ing. I came 2nd in most of game I played except the games these people played in.. their Kill streak was on average 20 per game they played.. amazingly they both appeared in the same games.. coincidence? you figure it out.

I would recommend this game to my friends, as I have done, but warned them of players using, apparently, hax already. This is going to be a fun game when done. Don't be put off by these sad players that need to hax. Dive in.

Game mechanics are good, maps are fun and it has a future. Different from the usual FPS/ Moba.

On a serious note I cannot give it a thumbs up till a anti-hack is introduced. Which I believe the devs will.. in time. Buy it.. play it.. support devs.. enjoy. Don't let hax idiots ruin our enjoyment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had a blast playing this and it has made some good progress. I really like what they've done with the earth school and all the classes really feel like their own. The fast paced  FPS action alone though makes this game a blast to play. It almost reminds me of Quake while at the same time reminding me of one of my all time favorite MMOs Darkfall. A lot of the spells feel really powerful and makes it that much sweeter when you crush someone with a boulder.

Now, what I feel the game needs to work on.

-Progression system

-Some sort of personalization(not necessarily a char creator)

-Active blocking. I would like to see a more active blocking system that prevents the use of spells, but allows you to mitigate incoming projectiles(not AOE or skills raining down on you). Currently the game leans heavily on just dps, which is great for a fps, but it takes away the feel of battle of epic mages" vibe that this game is going for.

-Siege game mode. You're a badass mage
recommended: but having to burst open keep doors(while being attacked from high up) and surviving through chokepoints to take the relic inside would be fun.\n"

Early Access Review

This is a really good game with excellent combat mechanics, but I feel it lacks some vital polishing up that come with early-access games. The community in this so far is quite small, but a very helpful and friendly one to play with. I had always wanted to play a mage/fps mutant-crossover and I feel with a little more development this will be a nice break from guns and bombs style fps that mainstream developers seem incapable of making otherwise. At the moment in early-access don't expect much in terms of holding your attention, but if it ever comes under $5 I would recommend giving it a go and hopefully the dev team listens to all our ideas for this games future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend this game. The way the combat feels at the moment is completely in sync with each element. Fire is devastating, dangerous and quick. Void is hit and miss, with a steady amount of damage. Ice is slow but reliable, and will freeze oponents. Lightning will be a quick suprise but doesn't hit too hard. Stone allows for durability while bleeding the enemy dry, and nature allows for a balance of utility and damage (plus the bonus of turning into a tiny squirrel-like-thing). The utility and defensive spells add just enough variety to keep the game from being the same few magic classes without making the number of spells too confusing.

The only downside is that it's not popular enough at the moment for a full game at 2 o'clock in the afternoon - also the void spell that grabs opponents sometimes flings them off the map... but I can live with that as long as I get to turn myself into a hurling mass of rock and crush six people to death.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you hate big guns but like magic, this game is for you.

Grimoire: Manastorm: A medieval fantastic mage FPS like the old school. A mixed between skyrim destruction magic and some MMORPG where you can cast some big destructive AOE spells.
Chose one among the six type of mage (fire, ice, earth, lightning, life, nether) with 4 unique offensiv spells to each plus some extra capacities (teleportation, energy shield, trap...) to enhance your fighting, then go to the arena to fight alone or in a teambattle.



The concept is original, simple and fun:
Each mage has a unique gameplay: Fire is powerfull but you need to get close to ennemies to attack efficiently; Ice is mostly a mid-close range AOE type; Earth is a close splash damage type; Lightning is the long range type...Of course all mages can attack at long or close range, but they have their pros and cons.

Contrary to most of the FPS, you don't need to find ammo, health or armor.
There is an auto heal, but  the regen rate is slow enough for not making you invincible during fights, and fast enough to recover if you manage to hide a moment.
Mage don't need bullets. However there is a cooldown for each spells. That's why you have to anticipate the ennemies moves and cast wisely in order to fight efficiently as the stronger is the spell the longer you have to wait.       TIME IS MANA" -Blood Elf.

What's more......................................The character control is easy and simple..............You don't need to crouch or crawl.


The game is still on alpha
date: the developper team is very small
recommended: but they are working hard to improve the game. Today i have noticed a huge improvement on system stability after a huge patch. Lets support them! :D"
